HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  This is a 48-year-old gentleman
who has had a known murmur for the last 15 years.  An
echocardiogram done in [**2116-10-28**] showed an ejection
fraction of 60 percent with 2 plus mitral regurgitation with
a flailed mitral leaflet, biatrial enlargement, and 1 plus
tricuspid regurgitation.  Cardiac catheterization showed
normal coronary arteries.  The patient was referred to Dr.
[**First Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] for mitral valve repair.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Hypercholesterolemia.
2. Premature ventricular contractions.
3. Myxomatous mitral valve disease.
4. Hay fever.
5. History of hand fractures bilaterally.
6. History of bronchitis and pneumonia one year ago.
7. Status post nasal septoplasty in [**2094**].
8. Status post eye surgery in [**2090**].


ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

PREOPERATIVE MEDICATIONS:
1. Lipitor 10 mg by mouth once per day.
2. Toprol-XL 25 mg by mouth once per day.
3. Aspirin 81 mg by mouth once per day.


SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient lives at home with his wife.  [**Name (NI) **]
denies tobacco, marijuana, cocaine, or intravenous drug
abuse.  He drinks alcohol occasionally.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted to [**Hospital1 346**] on [**2117-8-31**] and was taken to
the operating room with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] for a minimally
invasive mitral valve repair through a right mini-
thoracotomy.  Total cardiopulmonary bypass time was 132
minutes.  Cross-clamp time was 90 minutes.  Please see the
Operative Note for further details.

The patient was transported to the Intensive Care Unit in
stable condition.  The patient was weaned and extubated from
mechanical ventilation on his first postoperative night with
good hemodynamics.  The patient required some Neo-Synephrine
to maintain an adequate blood pressure on his first
postoperative night.  This was weaned to off by the morning
on postoperative day one, and the patient was transferred
from the Intensive Care Unit to the regular part of the
hospital.  The patient began ambulating with Physical
Therapy.

On postoperative day two, the patient's pacing wires and
chest tube were removed without incident.  Post chest tube
removal chest x-ray showed no pneumothorax, no effusion, and
mild edema.  The patient began working with Physical Therapy
and was able to ambulate 500 feet and climb one flight of
stairs while remaining hemodynamically stable.

By postoperative day three, the patient had been weaned off
of his oxygen.  He continued with ambulation.  He continued
to have stable hemodynamics, and the patient was cleared for
discharge on postoperative day four.

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE:  Temperature maximum was 97.5, his
pulse was 73 (sinus rhythm), his blood pressure was 117/61,
his respiratory rate was 18, and his oxygen saturation was 95
percent on room air.  Neurologically, the patient was awake,
alert, and oriented times three - nonfocal examination.
Heart was regular in rate and rhythm.  No murmurs or rubs.
Respiratory examination revealed breath sounds were decreased
on the right; otherwise, they were clear bilaterally.  The
right mini-thoracotomy incision was clean, dry, and intact.
There was no erythema or drainage.  The right groin incision
was clean and dry with no erythema or drainage.

MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE:
1. Toprol-XL 25 mg by mouth once per day.
2. Lasix 20 mg by mouth twice per day (times five days).
3. Potassium chloride 20 mEq by mouth twice per day (times
   five days).
4. Colace 100 mg by mouth twice per day.
5. Zantac 150 mg by mouth twice per day.
6. Enteric coated aspirin 325 mg by mouth once per day.
7. Percocet 5/325 one to two tablets by mouth q.4-6h. as
   needed.
8. Ibuprofen 600 mg by mouth q.6h. times three days and then
   q.6h. as needed.
9. Atorvastatin 10 mg by mouth once per day.


DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Mitral regurgitation.
2. Status post minimally invasive mitral valve repair.
3. Hypercholesterolemia.


DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:  The patient was to be discharged to
home in stable condition.

2. The patient was also instructed to follow up with his
